PROJECT PREPARATORY TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
 
A.  Justification 
 
1.  A  project  preparatory  technical  assistance  (PPTA)  is  required to  produce  a  project 
design which responds to the needs of the clients and fulfills requirements and safeguards 
policies of ADB. Given the complexity of the project, the PPTA will be implemented in two 
phases. In the first phase, the consulting team will (i) carry out initial sector, technical, and 
safeguards  assessments,  and  develop  preliminary  selection  criteria  for  the  agricultural 
enterprises,  farmer  cooperatives,  and  rural  financial  service  providers  borrowing  from  the 
project; and (ii) identify proper financing arrangements and loan modality for the project, and 
obtain consensus among the stakeholders including the National Development and Reform 
Commission, Ministry of Finance, executing agency, potential financial intermediaries, and ADB. 
In the second phase, the consulting team will undertake a detailed due diligence in technical 
feasibility,  economic  and  financial  viability,  and  safeguards.  Capacity  assessment  and 
strengthening will also be conducted, as needed. A medium-scale international conference on 
rural financial development will be held to help improve project design and share knowledge. To 
ensure the consistency in project design, one firm will be recruited to carry out the two phases 
of the PPTA.

Financing Partnership Facility and administered by ADB. The government will provide in-kind 
contributions in the form of counterpart staff, office accommodation, transportation to project

D.  Consulting Services 
4.  It is expected that 14 person-months of international and 38 person-months of national 
consultants are required. With additional funding from WFPF, 2 person-months of international 
and 4 person-months of national consultants will be added to strengthen the water-related 
project design. The consultants will be recruited through one consulting firm in accordance with 
ADB’s Guidelines on the Use of Consultants (2010, as amended from time to time) using 
quality- and cost-based selection method (with a quality-cost ratio of 90:10 considering the 
variety of expertise required and its critical role) following the simplified technical proposal.

E.  Implementation Arrangements 
6.  The Gansu Provincial Government will be the executing agency for the TA, and the 
Gansu  Provincial  Agricultural  and  Animal  Husbandry  Department  will  be  the  implementing 
agency.  The  multi-agency  leading  group  at  the  provincial  level  will  serve  as  the  steering 
committee. The steering committee will provide overall guidance on the TA’s implementation 
and ensure coordination across sectors during project preparation. A TA management office will 
be established at the Foreign Capital Project Management Office of the implementing agency. 
The TA management office will be responsible for day-to-day communications and operational 
matters  involving  ADB,  consultants,  and  related  government  agencies.  The  workshops, 
conference and training funds will be administered through the consultants. Advances provided 
for these events needs to be liquidated within 30 days after the event to ensure timely financial 
closing. The equipment will be purchased in accordance with ADB’s Procurement Guidelines 
(2013 as amended from time to time) and will be turned over to the executing agency upon 
completion  of  TA  activities.  The  disbursement  will  be  done  following  ADB’s  Technical 
Assistance Disbursement Handbook (2010, as amended from time to time). The TA will be 
implemented from 1 September 2013 to 1 December 2014.

OUTLINE OF TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR THE CONSULTANTS 
 
 
1.   Agricultural economist/team leader (international, 6.0 person-months [pm]). The specialist 
is expected to have (i) a postgraduate degree in agricultural economics or other related fields, (ii) 
over 15 years of experience in agricultural development in developing countries, (iii) demonstrated 
experience in leading the preparation of agricultural projects in the People’s Republic of China 
(PRC), and (iv) experience in preparing ADB financial intermediation loan is desirable. The specialist 
will assume overall technical and administrative responsibility for effectively implementing the project 
preparatory technical assistance (PPTA) and delivering quality outputs on time. Specifically, the 
specialist will undertake the following: (i) coordinate with ADB, the executing agency, and other 
related  government  agencies  during  PPTA  implementation;  (ii)  make  reasonable  plans  and 
allocation of team resources for the two phases of the PPTA;  (iii) direct all team members on their 
schedule and technical inputs to ensure timely inputs from the team members; (iv) conduct quality 
control and consolidation of the consultants’ inputs and take ultimate responsibility for the TA 
reports; (v) organize team’s field activities including field visits, data collection, meetings, workshops, 
and trainings; (vi) review the domestic feasibility study report and strengthen the project design 
based on consultation with the team and key stakeholders; (vii) review and summarize experiences 
and lessons of past ADB and other multilateral development institutions’ projects in agriculture and 
rural finance in the PRC; (viii) guide the national agricultural economist and financial specialist in 
preparing sector assessment, cost estimate and financing plan, and economic and financial analysis 
of the project; (ix) develop a coherent rationale for the project with associated problem tree analysis 
and project design and monitoring framework; and (x) prepare a draft project administration manual 
with assistance from the deputy team leader.  
 
2.   Rural  financial  specialist/deputy  team  leader  (national,  6.0  pm).  The  specialist  is 
expected to have (i) a postgraduate degree in economics, finance, or other relevant fields, (ii) over 
10 years of experience in rural financial services development, and (iii) sufficient knowledge on 
financial sector regulatory and development policies. The specialist will undertake the following: (i) 
support the team leader and liaise with the team to ensure that the PPTA team works efficiently and 
carries out tasks in a timely manner; (ii) assist the team leader in consolidating reports submitted by 
team  members  and  preparing  overall  TA  reports,  with  focus  on  parts  related  to  financial 
development and financing arrangements; (iii) assist the team leader in organizing field visits, data 
collection, meetings, workshops, and trainings; (iv) prepare sector assessment on current rural 
financial services system in Gansu Province; and (v) work with the international rural financial 
specialist on the specified tasks. 
 
3.  Rural financial specialist (international, 2.5 pm). The specialist is expected to have (i) a 
postgraduate degree in economics, finance, or other relevant fields, (ii) over 10 years of experience 
in development and operations of rural finance institutions or microfinance institutions, and (iii) 
gained knowledge on rural financial development through international consultancy work or as 
employee/advisor of financial institutions. Experience and knowledge of rural finance in the PRC and 
expertise demonstrated through research articles or publications are desirable. The specialist will 
work  closely  with  the  national  rural  financial  specialist/deputy  team  leader  to:  (i)  summarize 
experience and lesions of ADB and other donors in rural financial development, and recommend 
international experience and best practices for the local governments; (ii) assess the feasibility of the 
proposed project design with respect to rural financial services development and refine the design; 
(iii) help design surveys to understand the existing demand for and supply of financial services in 
rural area; (iv) prepare designs for establishing and managing rural financial development fund 
under  the  project;  (v)  develop  activities  in  credit  rating  for  rural  financial  institution,  financial 
education, new collaterals, and other innovative financial products or services that could be trialed 
under the project; (vi) support financial institution specialists in setting up the parameter for selecting

eligible microfinance and rural finance institutions for onlending and conducting quantitative and 
qualitative  review  of  the  candidate  institutions;  and  (vii)  design  and  coordinate  international 
conference on rural financial development. 
 
4.  Agricultural insurance specialist (national, 2.0 pm). The specialist is expected to have (i) a 
postgraduate degree in economics, finance, or other relevant fields, (ii) over 10 years of experience 
in developing agricultural insurance program in developing context, and (iii) sufficient knowledge on 
insurance policies and regulation in the PRC. The specialist will work closely with the rural financial 
specialists to: (i) review agricultural insurance status in Gansu Province, summarize experience and 
lesions of ADB and other donors in agricultural insurance in developing countries, and recommend 
measures to strengthen agricultural insurance in terms of policy reform, institutional capacity, and 
practices;  (ii)  investigate  the  desirability  and  feasibility  of  introducing  innovative  agricultural 
insurance instruments, such as index-based insurance, in the project area; (iii) propose agricultural 
insurance interventions that could be incorporated into or trialed under the project; (iv) provide inputs 
on improving project design, particularly combining insurance with credit in the project, and on 
insurance component of rural financial development fund to be established under the project; and (v) 
assist  rural  financial  specialists  in  organizing  the  international  conference  on  rural  financial 
development. 
 
5.  Agricultural specialist (national, 3.0 pm). The specialist will have (i) a postgraduate degree 
in agriculture, agronomy, or other relevant fields, and (ii) over 10 years of experience in dryland 
farming, crop adjustment and/or agricultural value chains development in the PRC. The specialist 
will: (i) assess existing practices and productivity of featured agriculture in the project area, and 
identify key technical constraints, as well as constraints in value chains development and farmer 
incentives; (ii) review and assess the viability, soundness, and completeness of the  executing 
agency’s proposals in developing production and processing bases and supporting agricultural 
enterprises and farmer cooperatives and propose improvement to the proposals; (iii) review existing 
farm management practices in the project area and propose improvements to be incorporated in 
project design; (iv) assist in data collection and analysis for economic and financial analysis; and (v) 
assist  in  developing  criteria  for  selecting  enterprises  and  farmer  cooperatives  to  be  the  final 
borrowers.  
 
6.  Livestock farming specialist (national, 1.0 pm). The specialist will have (i) a master’s 
degree in domestic animal husbandry and/or equivalent experience, (ii) at least 10 years of national 
experience in the development and management of the livestock industry, including in the arid 
regions of western PRC, (iii) an expert understanding of all facets of the livestock industry, including 
animal husbandry, waste disposal, sourcing of feed, use of growth hormones, varieties suited to the 
western PRC, and culling and welfare, and (iv) the development and use of biogas as a method for 
disposal of livestock waste. The specialist will undertake the following tasks: (i) assess and describe 
the current status of livestock farming across the project sites, including a list of all existing ventures 
and a summary of their attributes, an estimate of the types and volumes of feed being used, 
locations and types of feed sources and lands, estimate of the volume of livestock waste generated, 
disposal methods for livestock waste, and existing conditions and methods for breeding, raising, and 
culling; (ii) review plans for livestock development and current licensing systems; (iii) based on 
proposed project designs, estimate the: (a) increased feed requirements and waste production, (b) 
extent of new lands that may be required for production of livestock and/or feed, and (c) increased 
energy consumption; (iv) assess the capacity of the project recipients to manage the increased 
requirements of feed, husbandry, land, waste disposal, and humane treatment (raising and culling) 
of livestock; (v) develop conclusions and recommendations regarding the proposed project livestock 
targets; (vi) identify training needs to improve livestock management; and (vii) assess the findings in 
relation to provincial and national regulations.

7.  Financial specialist (national, 4.0 pm). The specialist will have (i) a bachelor’s degree or 
higher in finance, accounting or other relevant fields with a Certified Public Accountant qualification, 
and (ii) at least 10 years of experience in conducting financial analysis of agricultural investment and 
rural finance. The specialist will undertake the following tasks: (i) conduct financial analysis of the 
revenue-generating activities and entities under the project in accordance with ADB’s Financial 
Management and Analysis of Projects  (2005); (ii) develop the detailed cost estimates by cost 
category and by project component; (iii) propose the financing plan, design fund flow mechanism, 
and identify appropriate ADB disbursement procedure, based on the project need and executing 
agency/implementing agency capacity to manage funds flow and disbursement; (iv) assess the 
financial sustainability identify major risks, and propose mitigation measures; and (v) undertake a 
financial management assessment of the executing agencies and key implementing agencies.  
 
8.  Agricultural  economist  (national,  3.0  pm).  The  specialist  will  have  (i)  a  postgraduate 
degree in economics or other relevant fields, (ii) over 10 years of experience in conducting economic 
analysis of agricultural investment, and (iii) sufficient knowledge of rural finance services. The 
specialist will undertake the following tasks: (i) conduct sector assessment of featured agricultural 
production and value chain development in Gansu Province; (ii) conduct detailed demand analysis 
for targeted products; (iii) propose criteria for selecting final borrowers and targeting beneficiaries; 
(iv)  cooperate  with  social  specialists  in  designing  household  surveys  for  sector  assessment, 
beneficiaries  targeting  and  economic  analysis;  (iv)  assist  the  international  agricultural 
economist/team leader in preparing economic analysis in line with ADB’s Handbook on Economic 
Analysis, covering least cost analysis, cost-benefit analysis, sensitivity and risk analysis, among 
others; and (v) assist the international agricultural economist/team leader in designing performance 
indicators and monitoring arrangements.  
 
9.  Social development specialists (international, 2.0 pm; national, 3.0 pm). The specialist will 
have at least a master degree (international) and at least a bachelor's degree (national) in an applied 
social science. The specialist will have at least  7 years (international) and at least five years 
(national) of experience working on internationally financed projects, preferably with experience in 
multiple countries. Experience in rural development projects is essential. The role of the specialists 
is to prepare design elements that make the project socially and economically inclusive in the sense 
that the poor, vulnerable, and excluded households will benefit from the project, and that it will 
contribute to increased gender equity. For this, they will prepare design document, such as a social 
action plan, including gender design features, pro-poor design features and design features reducing 
vulnerability, improve consultation and participation, and participation of civil society. They will 
ensure that cooperatives and participating enterprises are bound to these plans, and the design 
elements will be fixed, besides in separate plans, in all relevant project design documents. To this 
effect, they will cooperate with other PPTA team members and ensure close design cooperation. 
The international specialist will have an oversight role for the national social development, social 
safeguards, and rural development specialists, and coordination role with the overall PPTA team. 
The specialists will undertake the following tasks: (i) assess information needs to conduct the 
required activities, in particular poverty, vulnerability, and gender data of the project areas; (ii) collect 
available secondary data; (iii) prepare and conduct surveys to fulfill the needs of primary information 
collection; (iv) establish a baseline on poverty and vulnerability in the project area; (v) design project 
elements to achieve inclusiveness and gender equity through the project; (vi) integrate these design 
elements in separate social and gender action plans (and other plans, if deemed appropriate) and 
into project design documents such as project administration manual, report and recommendations 
of the President, loan agreement, project agreement, etc., including budget, implementation, and 
monitoring  procedures;  (vii)  ensure  that  such  design  elements  are  endorsed  by  other  PPTA 
members, design institutes, and executing agency and implementing agencies; and (viii) prepare 
inputs to all PPTA reports.

10.  Social  safeguards  specialist  (national,  3.0  pm).  The  specialist  will  have  at  least  a 
bachelor's degree in an applied social science. The specialist will have at least 5 years of experience 
working  on  internationally  financed  projects  with  rural  land  acquisition  impact,  and  in-depth 
knowledge of current PRC legislation regarding land acquisition, land tenure consolidation and land 
lease.  The  specialist  will  have  proven  experience  in  establishing  ethnic  minority  development 
planning or similar actions in ethnic minority areas. The role of the specialist is to ensure impacts of 
land use changes are handled or mitigated in a way that nobody affected is worse off after the 
project, and preferably better off; and to ensure that ethnic minorities are among the beneficiaries of 
the project as feasible. The specialist will undertake the following tasks: (i) establish a baseline of 
land use needed for project land activities; (ii) assess land acquisition impacts of project activities, 
and ensure that construction and other activities' planning minimizes these; (iii) prepare resettlement 
plans or framework commensurate with impacts; (iv) ensure that project design and loan covenants 
prohibit physical displacement; (v) establish, together with land resources bureau and agricultural 
bureau, the feasibility and legal status of land consolidation and land lease arrangements, and 
prepare loan covenants governing these; (vi) prepare a due diligence on land lease and land 
consolidation arrangements to be used under the project; (vii) assess potential benefits of the project 
to ethnic minorities and establish a baseline regarding these benefits; (viii) establish rules under 
which ethnic minorities can participate in project activities in form of a ethnic minority development 
plan  commensurate  with  the  project  impacts,  and  (ix)  prepare  an  Environmental  and  Social 
Management System if FI modality is adopted. 
 
11.  Farmer cooperative cum agricultural SME development specialist (national, 4.0 pm). 
The specialist will have at least a bachelor's degree in an applied social science. The specialist will 
have at least 5 years of experience working on internationally financed projects in rural development. 
The  role  of  the  specialist  is  to  participate  in  project  design  to  ensure  the  cooperatives  and 
enterprises participating are selected in an appropriate way, that activities financed under the project 
make social and economic sense, and that the project activities are designed to allow them being 
socially and economically inclusive in the sense that poor, vulnerable and excluded households will 
benefit  from  the  project.  The  specialist  will  undertake  the  following  tasks:  (i)  collect  available 
secondary and needed primary data on current status of agricultural technology, development of 
cooperatives  and  status,  of  small  and medium  agricultural  enterprises  in  the  project  area;  (ii) 
cooperate with other specialists  and institutes to establish screening criteria and a screening 
process for the eligibility of participating enterprises and cooperatives; (iii) establish organizational 
models for participating enterprises and cooperatives; (iv) establish business models for participating 
enterprises and cooperatives, including branding, marketing, selection of market niches such as 
organic production, and niche or mainstream products; (v) prepare a consultation and participation 
process  to  inform  potential  participating  enterprises  and  cooperatives,  and  communities in  the 
project areas, about the project and the possibility of benefitting from the project; (vi) ensure the 
selection process and eligibility criteria, business models, participation processes, are endorsed by 
executing agency and implementing agencies, and integrated into project design documents such as 
project  administration  manual,  report  and  recommendations  of  the  President,  loan  agreement, 
project agreement, etc., including budget, implementation, and monitoring procedures; and (vii) 
prepare inputs to all PPTA reports. 
 
12.  Environmental specialists (international, 2.0 pm; national, 3.0 pm). The specialists will 
have (i) a master’s degree in environment studies and/or equivalent experience; (ii) at least 10 years 
international and national experience respectively in environment impact assessment, including 
demonstrated experience on Environmental Impact Assessment for the agricultural and livestock 
industry; (iii) familiarity with the ADB Safeguard Policy for environment (SPS, 2009) and a track 
record in the preparation of environment impact assessments for international development banks. 
The specialists will be responsible for the overall assessment of project potential environmental 
impacts and assisting the Gansu Provincial Government to identify and prepare the necessary 
environmental documents to achieve compliance with the SPS. The specialists will: (i) through

desktop review, site surveys, and meetings with the design institutes, describe the environmental 
conditions  and  key  issues  relevant  to  the  project;  (ii)  assess  potential  extent  and  impacts  of 
increased use of agricultural chemicals, water, electricity, and greenhouse gas emissions, and 
increased agricultural and livestock waste, which may result from the project, (iii) prepare the project 
environmental documents (initial environmental examination and environmental assessment and 
review framework), including: (a) the study area, existing conditions, and relevant regulations and 
policies; (b) methods; (c) potential project environmental impacts; (d) mitigation measures; and (e) 
an environmental management plan, describing the mitigation measures, a monitoring program, 
training activities, responsible agencies and institutional arrangements, implementation schedule 
and costs, and a grievance redress mechanism, and (iv) prepare an Environmental and Social 
Management System if FI modality is adopted. 
 
13.  Financial institution specialists (international, 1.5 pm; national, 4.0 pm). The specialist is 
expected to have (i) a bachelor’s or higher degree in finance, accounting or other relevant fields, (ii) 
sufficient knowledge with banking rules and regulations in the PRC, and (iii) over 5 years practical 
experience  in  the  banking  sector  and  reviewing  finance  information  and  annual  reports.  The 
specialists  will  undertake  the  following  tasks:  (i) propose  objective  and  transparent  criteria  for 
selecting the commercial banks to act as the financial intermediaries under the project; (ii) conduct a 
comprehensive  assessment  covering  the  willingness  and  experience,  business  strategy,  
governance, operating environment, etc. of candidate banking institutions identified for financial 
intermediaries;  (iii)  undertake  a  CAMELS+  (C  –  Capital  Adequacy,  A  –  Asset  Quality,  M  – 
Management quality, E – Earnings, L – Liquidity, S – Sensitivity to Market) review of the candidate 
banking institutions. The results of the assessment and review will be used to select suitable 
partners to support project interventions in the rural finance and microcredit space; (iv) propose 
auditing and accounting procedures and financial management procedures in accordance with 
ADB’s fiduciary requirements for financial intermediation lending and ADB’s anticorruption policy; (v) 
design  criteria  for  selecting  rural  financial  institutions  to  receive  lending  from  the  financial 
intermediaries; (vi) prepare guidelines and requirements for rural financial institutions to lend loan 
proceeds  to  end-borrowers;  (vii)  propose  the  eligibility  criteria  for  selecting  the  financial 
intermediaries to be engaged to provide implementation and administration support to the executing 
agency in selecting final borrowers, executing sub-loan agreements with final borrowers, making 
disbursement, and collecting payment of interest and principal when due from the final borrowers; 
(viii) conduct due diligence on the selected financial intermediaries; and (ix) prepare draft or provide 
inputs to agreements involving ADB, the executing agency, financial intermediaries and/or rural 
financial institutions.  
 
14.  Project management and procurement specialist (national, 2.0 pm). The specialist will 
have (i) a bachelor’s or higher degree in agriculture or other relevant fields, and (ii) 10 years of work 
experience in procurement for agricultural investment and consulting services. The specialist will 
undertake the following tasks: (i) conduct procurement capacity assessment for the executing and 
implementing agencies, project management office and project implementation offices to undertake 
procurement and consultant recruitments under the project; (ii) prepare a procurement plan and 
sample bidding documents; (iii) assess the capacity of the executing and implementing agencies for 
project implementation, and propose measures to strengthen their capacity and collaboration with 
relevant government agencies; and (iv) provide trainings on project management, procurement, and 
consulting services.  
 
15.  Water resource specialists (international 1.0 pm, national, 2.0 pm). The specialists will 
have (i) a master’s degree in hydrology or water resources management, (ii) at least 10 years of 
international and 5 years of national experience respectively in water balance analyses and water for 
agricultural use, and (iii) expert understanding of surface and groundwater hydrology, preferably in 
the arid regions of western PRC. The specialists will do the following. For output 1: (i) describe the 
existing water resources across the project sites, including surface and ground water supplies, water

quality in the key aquifers and rivers, and existing impacts from agricultural chemicals and livestock 
waste; (ii) review existing policies and procedures for agricultural water use and water licensing, 
permits, and allocation for farming; (iii) describe existing water-saving practices in local farming, (iv) 
characterize the proposed water demands of the project; (v) develop a model to estimate total 
expected increase in water demands from the project - as far as possible, assess the sustainability 
of this increase, (noting also the need for other water allocations e.g. for ecological flows); (vi) apply

and other buildings e.g. installation of water meters to measure usage, dual-flush toilets, and

Summarize the findings in a final report and knowledge product. 
 
16.  Climate change specialist (international, 1.0 pm). The specialist will have (i) a master’s 
degree in climate change and/or equivalent experience and skills; (ii) at least 5 years of experience 
in climate change and agricultural modeling; and (iii) demonstrated ability in the use of international 
climate modeling software (e.g., Climate Map). The specialist will undertake the following tasks: (i) 
conduct a baseline assessment of predicted climate change in the project area and how this may 
affect project design, including crop and livestock selection, tolerance to drier and hotter conditions, 
and water demand and supply; and (ii) with the agricultural, livestock and water resource specialists, 
develop recommendations for farming practices, including crop and livestock selection, and water 
management, which will strengthen resilience to drought and rising temperatures. 
 
17.   Agriculture and water extension specialist (national, 2.0 pm). The specialist will have a 
bachelor’s or master’s degree in agricultural sciences or similar relevant studies, and several years 
of experience in agriculture in water-constrained provinces in the PRC. The specialist will equally 
have experience in establishing participatory systems, working with cooperatives and small and 
medium agricultural enterprises on value chain development, marketing, and input provision. The 
specialist will undertake the following tasks: (i) ensure systems are put into place and that innovative 
and water-saving practices are available in a sustainable way and understood by the participating 
enterprises or cooperatives and farmers; (ii) participate in other specialists' activities on water saving 
practices in local farming, and provide input to other specialists; (iii) based on results and plans 
provided  by  other  specialists,  in  particular  the  specialist  on  ecological  agriculture,  prepare,  in 
consultation  and  under  participation  of  farmers  and  project-participating  enterprises,    training 
schedules  for  farmers,  schedules  for  field  trials/farmer  field  schools,  schedules  for  technical 
procedures  to  be  applied  in  enterprises/cooperatives,  schedules/manuals  for  marketing  and 
branding by enterprises/cooperatives, and other schedules and manuals as required; and (iv) run 
trial farmer field schools, and support enterprises/cooperatives in application of the schedules and 
manuals.
